title: Guide to ABM Metrics | 6sense
meta_description: Master ABM metrics measurement with our complete guide. Explore account-based marketing metrics, benchmarks, and dashboard strategies for revenue growth.
p: ABM metrics are the cornerstone of successful account-based marketing strategies, providing crucial insights into engagement, pipeline development, and revenue impact across your target accounts. However, recent research reveals a measurement crisis in B2B marketing. | Reach:A measure of the unique people within target accounts that have seen a campaign | View-through rate:The rate at which people who viewed an ad then visit your website, even if they didn’t click on the ad itself | Buying group engagement:Measurement of multiple stakeholders within target accounts interacting with your content | Account engagement scores:Anonymous behavior tracking that reveals buying group interest

In our recent report,What’s (Currently) Measured Isn’t What Matters: The State of B2B Marketing Metrics in 2025, nearly 80% of organizations report having an ABM program, but only 29% of ABM teams are measured solely through ABM-aligned metrics.
This reveals a significant disconnect: Marketers are doing one thing (ABM) but measuring another (leads and MQLs), undermining ABM effectiveness and making it difficult to prove true ROI.
This comprehensive framework will help you bridge that gap and evolve your account-based marketing measurement approach.

Account-based metrics are specialized key performance indicators that measure marketing’s impact on specific target accounts rather than individual leads.Unlike traditional marketing metrics that emphasize volume and quantity, ABM metrics prioritize quality, engagement depth, and revenue impact from strategically selected accounts.
These metrics enable marketing and sales teams to track how effectively they’re engaging entire buying groups throughout the customer journey, ultimately driving more predictable revenue growth.
How to measure account-based marketing | Measuring account-based marketing requires a shift from lead-based to account-centric measurement approaches. Key ABM metrics to track include:

The 2025 report shows that nearly half of ABM adoptersstill measure success by MQLs, even from non-target accounts.This uncovers a fundamental misalignment between ABM strategy and measurement practice, where marketing qualified accounts from target accounts are tracked almost equally with marketing qualified leads from non-target accounts (49% vs. 44%). By treating strategically selected target accounts the same as random inbound leads, it’s difficult for ABM teams to assess whether account-based investments are generating better results than traditional efforts.

Establishing internal benchmarks | Your internal benchmarks should reflect your specific industry, deal size, and sales cycle characteristics. Consider these factors when establishing your measurement framework:

Finally, consider both sourced and influenced attribution approaches based on your use case and buying cycle length. With typically long B2B buying cycles, source-based attribution can be problematic because it credits a single “first touch” that may have occurred months before any serious buying activity began, ignoring the complex research and evaluation process that actually drives purchase decisions. Measuring influence or lift can offer advantages since it captures marketing’s impact across the entire buying journey, accounting for how campaigns affect conversion rates, deal velocity, and win rates throughout the extended evaluation.

What are the three pillars of ABM metrics? | These three pillars of ABM success metrics provide a comprehensive framework for measuring account-based marketing effectiveness across the entire customer journey.

The earliestand often most criticalstage of the buyer journey. This pillar focuses on measuring how effectively you reach and engage your target accounts before they enter formal sales processes.Given that 84% of buyers have already selected their preferred vendorbefore contacting sellers, the awareness and engagement stage is paramount for earning consideration from buying groups.

Understanding awareness and engagement addresses a major challenge in modern B2B marketing:Most buyer research happens anonymously and across multiple touchpoints. The solution is to gather intent data that ties anonymous research activities to specific accounts and provides clues about which buyer personas are actively engaged. AI analysis of intent signals can then predict the buying stage of accounts.

For instance, when more than one member of the same buying team is researching your brand or related solutions, that sends a signal that the team is serious about purchasing, enabling marketing teams to identify and prioritize accounts showing genuine purchase intent rather than casual browsing behavior.

2. Pipeline progression metrics | This pillar measures how effectively engaged accounts convert into viable sales opportunities. Pipeline development metrics bridge the gap between marketing engagement and sales outcomes, providing visibility into how effectively marketing activities translate into qualified opportunities.

Unlike traditional lead-based approaches that focus on individual qualification, pipeline development metrics examine account-level progression and buying group completeness. This perspective becomes crucial for organizations seeking to demonstrate marketing’s strategic value beyond lead generation, particularly when sales cycles are lengthy and involve complex stakeholder dynamics. The focus shifts from counting individual leads to understanding how entire accounts move through consideration stages, plus how marketing efforts influence the speed and quality of that progression.
It’s not about generating leads; it’s about generating stage-by-stage pipeline value that translates into revenue.

According to research fromThe Impact of ABM Metrics on Financial Performance, ABM-centric metrics are more strongly correlated with better financial performance than traditional measurements. This pillar captures not just immediate revenue attribution but also long-term account value and program efficiency.

Our 2025 report revealed thatonly 13% of ABM programs report closed-won revenueto leadership.This is ahuge strategic gapthat can undermine investment in ABM efforts. Revenue impact metrics provide the business case for continued ABM investment while demonstrating marketing’s direct contribution to organizational growth objectives.

Rather than simply tracking whether deals close, this pillar examines the quality and sustainability of revenue generated through ABM efforts, including expansion opportunities within accounts and the overall return on marketing investments. These ABM success metrics work together to provide complete visibility into program performance, enabling a focus on lifetime customer value that drives sustainable revenue growth.

Traditional marketing metrics vs. account-based marketing metrics | The shift from traditional lead-based marketing to account-based marketing represents a major change in how B2B organizations measure success. This transition reflects the reality of modern B2B buying, where decisions are made by groups rather than individuals, and lengthy evaluation processes require sustained engagement strategies.

A lot of common consumer marketing metrics are a poor fit for B2B. Sure, they tell you something about how and where someone engaged with a piece of content. But the devil is in the lack of details, as noted inthis 6sense guide. Traditional metrics emphasize volume and individual actions:
For quick buying cycles involving a single decision-maker, they work great. For B2B, they fall short.
Quality vs. quantity:Traditional metrics often reward high-volume activities, while ABM metrics emphasize engagement quality and depth within strategically selected accounts.
Individual vs. group:Legacy approaches track individual lead behavior, whereas ABM metrics monitor buying group dynamics and collective account activities.
Attribution complexity:Account-based teams rely on both sourced and influenced attribution, with 57% using combined approaches, recognizing the multi-touch nature of B2B buying journeys.
The persistence of these legacy practices suggests that while account-based teams are adopting new marketing methods, measurement practices are more difficult to replace.

Creating an effectiveABM metrics dashboardrequires careful planning, stakeholder alignment, and ongoing optimization. Your dashboard should provide actionable insights for both marketing and sales teams while demonstrating clear business impact to executive leadership.

title: Lead Generation Strategy: The Perfect Guide | 6sense
meta_description: Discover the guide to crafting a winning B2B lead generation strategy. Uncover tactics, tools, and best practices for successful outbound lead generation.
p: How do you define lead generation? Well, it’s not just about finding potential customers.It’s about finding therightcustomersand knowing exactly how to guide them on a journey towards becomingloyalcustomers.
Of course, that’s easier said than done! According to a 2021 survey from Ruler Analytics,37% of B2B marketersconsider generating high-quality leads their top challenge.
If you’re struggling with the same challenge, this guide is for you. We’re going to:
Quick Take: B2B lead generation should focus on targetingmultiple peoplewithinorganizations, not just individuals.
Lead generation is the systematic process of identifying, engaging, and nurturing visitors who fit your buyer personas andideal customer profile (ICP).
This process is especially critical for B2B companies, where complex decision-making processes and longer sales cycles require a sophisticated approach.
B2B vs. B2C lead generation: understanding the difference | While B2B and B2C lead generation share the same core concept, their execution differs significantly.

For B2C companies, lead generation strategies targetindividual consumers. The company must craft messaging and strategies that appeal to the personal preferences and needs of these individual buyers. It often involves a shortersales processand a focus on a broader audience.

For B2B companies, lead generation means engaging withorganizations, each with its own structure, decision-making units, and unique pain points. B2B leads are typically acquired through relationships with key decision-makers, extensive research, and tailored strategies that cater to a nichetarget audience.
Key components of a successful lead generation strategy | Quick Take: Know your buyer and their pain points. Then respect their time by delivering value in every interaction.

Buyer personas and target audience identification | First, you must understand your audience. Start by creating detailed buyer personas representing your ideal customers. That means diving deep into their pain points, motivations, and behaviors.

For instance, if you’re a B2B software provider, a buyer persona might be “IT Manager John,” who seeks efficient solutions to streamline operations and prioritize data security. He might also be responsible for managing a team of tech professionals, and prioritize tools that optimize workflow while assisting withregulatory compliance.

Offer each persona a clear value proposition | To stand out in a sea of competitors, you need to articulate why prospects should choose your offering over others. Your value propositions should answer the lead’s question, “What’s in it for me?”

Landing pages and lead magnets | Once you’ve captured your audience’s attention with tailored messaging, you need a place to direct them — a landing page. An effective landing page converts visitors into leads by encouraging them to take a specific action, such as signing up for a free trial, requesting a demo, or downloading a resource.

Effective landing pages are clean, focused, and centered around a single call-to-action (CTA). They should also match the messaging that brought visitors there in the first place, providing a seamless experience.
When using web forms to collect contact data, you can incentivize visitors to exchange their contact information for valuable content like ebooks, whitepapers, or webinars.

Gating all of your valuable content can be self-defeating, though, sincemany visitors avoid filling out web forms. Make sure prospects who are early in their buying journey can do effective self-serve research on your site. Otherwise, they’ll go elsewhere.

Lead nurturing workflows | Once you’ve captured leads, your goal is to guide and nurture them through the buyer’s journey, from initial awareness to the final decision-making stage. This process involves providing relevant, valuable content at each step to keep your leads engaged and informed.

Imagine your buyer persona has just downloaded your ebook on CRM software. Now, it’s time to nurture this lead. You might start with a series of automated emails discussing the CRM’s top benefits, best practices, and success stories. As the lead progresses through these emails, they gain a clearer understanding of how your software can revolutionize their company’s operations.

Effective lead nurturing workflowsare also personalized and well-timed. They adapt to each lead’s behavior and engagement level. If your lead clicks on an email link about data security, you can tailor later emails to focus more on this aspect of your software.
B2B lead generation strategies | Quick Take: You need an omnichannel approach to reach and influence buyers. The tactics below reinforce one another.
Now that we’ve established the core components of a successful lead generation strategy, let’s dive into some specialized B2B lead generation tactics that can supercharge your efforts.

Content marketing for lead gen | In-depth, industry-specific content is a powerful tool. Think whitepapers, case studies, video tutorials, and informative blog posts tailored to your ideal buyer’s pain points and interests.
For example, let’s say you offer cybersecurity services, and your ideal buyer is Alex, a Chief Information Security Officer at a financial institution. What type of content can you create?

Regardless of the content format, the goal of this lead generation tactic is to leave your buyer persona thinking, “This company truly understands the unique challenges we face and can provide the solution we need.”

For instance, if you’re a SaaS company offering different software solutions, you wouldn’t want to send the same email to a startup founder and a Chief Technology Officer of a large enterprise. They have distinct needs and interests.
When emailing a list of prospects, your audiences should be carefully segmented so you can deliver relevant campaigns.
Consider employing automation with6sense’s Conversational Email toolto streamline your email efforts. It can:
Social media outreach strategies | Social media platforms are valuable B2B lead generation tools. However, it’s crucial to approach social media outreach with a clear strategy in mind.

First, identify the social media channels where your target audience is most active. For B2B, platforms like LinkedIn and X (formerly Twitter) are often hotspots for professional networking and lead generation.

Next, you’ll want to engage with decision-makers, join industry groups, and share content that resonates with your audience and positions you as a thought leader. For example, you might share insightful articles on industry trends, comment on relevant posts, and participate in group discussions to establish your expertise.

Paid social advertising is another avenue to explore. LinkedIn in particular is a goldmine for this type of B2B lead generation. According to a recent report,nearly 85% of B2B teams use LinkedInduring the buying process. For a step-by-step guide on using LinkedIn to generate high-quality leads, check out these5 Recipes for Creating Effective, Perfectly Timed LinkedIn Ad Campaigns.
Webinars and events for B2B leads | Webinars and events are also excellent tools for showcasing your expertise, interacting directly with your target audience, and collecting valuable B2B leads.

Consider this scenario: You’re a marketing consultancy firm specializing in SEO services. You can attract marketing managers, business owners, and SEO enthusiasts by hosting a webinar titled “Mastering SEO Trends for 2024.”

During the webinar, you can provide valuable information, share success stories, and offer actionable tips. Attendees who find your content helpful are more likely to engage with your brand and consider your services in the future.

Industry conferences and trade shows also offer excellent opportunities for B2B lead generation. These events gather professionals and decision-makers in one place, providing you with a captive audience interested in your industry.

To maximize the impact of webinars and events, consider offering incentives for attendees to share their contact information. For example, you can provide access to exclusive resources, downloadable materials, or special discounts in exchange for their details.
If you’re using 6sense, you have even more options for lead generation from events.

Cold outreach and personalized messaging | Cold outreach, combined with personalized messaging, is a B2B lead generation technique that can yield remarkable results when executed strategically. This approach involves reaching out to potential leads who may not be familiar with your brand or offerings.

The key to successful cold outreach is personalization. Generic, one-size-fits-all messages are unlikely to grab the attention of busy professionals. Instead, you must craft tailored messages that address each recipient’s specific pain points, needs, and interests.

Start by conducting thorough research on your prospects. Understand their roles, challenges, and objectives within their organizations. This information will be invaluable in customizing your outreach.

For instance, if you offer HR software solutions, and your target is the HR manager of a mid-sized tech company, your message might begin by acknowledging the unique challenges HR managers face in tech environments. You can then highlight how your software streamlines HR processes and improves efficiency.

Intent datais a huge advantage for this type of outreach, since it can let you know which leads are likely to be receptive, and it also give you insights into the topics they are likely to care about.

Using automation for lead generation | Quick Take: Basic automations save time and ensure prospects receive valuable information. Automations triggered by AI can quickly respond to account behavior, keeping your messaging on point.

Picture this: You’ve got a team of tireless virtual assistants working around the clock, ensuring your message lands right in the laps of your dream clients precisely when they’re most receptive. How? Automation.
Here are some automation strategies that can streamline and optimize your lead generation efforts.

Email marketing automation | Email marketing automation tools allow you to send targeted and personalized email campaigns to leads based on their behavior and preferences. By tracking actions such as email opens, link clicks, and content downloads, you can segment your email list and deliver relevant content.

For example, suppose a lead has shown interest in a specific product or service. In that case, automation can trigger a series of follow-up emails that provide more in-depth information and nurture the lead further down the sales funnel.

CRM (customer relationship management) software | A CRM system centralizes lead data and interactions, enabling your team to manage and track leads effectively. By recording all touchpoints with leads — including emails, calls, and meetings — you gain a holistic view of each lead’s journey.

This information helps sales and marketing teams tailor their communication, identify opportunities for follow-up, and provide a more personalized experience, ultimately increasing the chances of conversions.

Chatbots | Chatbots offer real-time engagement on your website, providing immediate responses to visitor inquiries. They can also collect basic lead information, such as names and email addresses, and initiate conversations.
For instance, a chatbot can ask visitors if they’d like to subscribe to your newsletter or receive a downloadable resource, capturing leads.
Lead scoringassigns numerical values to leads based on their engagement and behavior. This allows you to prioritize leads and focus your efforts on those likely to convert.

For example, leads who have visited your pricing page, downloaded a product brochure, and interacted with your emails might receive a higher lead score. Automation can then trigger actions when leads reach specific score thresholds, such as notifying the sales team to reach out to high-scoring leads immediately.

Analytics and reporting | Automation in analytics tools helps you track and measure the performance of your lead generation campaigns in real time. This data provides insights into which strategies are most effective, enabling you to continually make data-driven decisions and optimize your lead generation efforts.
For example, you can automatically generate reports that show the ROI of specific marketing campaigns, helping you allocate resources more efficiently.

6sense makes marketing more powerful by enablingAI for lead generation, allowing marketing and sales teams tocreate audience segmentsbased on what buyers are interested in and what stage of the buying process they are in.

Accounts often take several months to make B2B purchases. During this period, they may be exploring a variety of topics. 6sense can detect buying indicators that tell you what accounts are currently looking into. This data can help you create personalized campaigns tailored to the precise needs of each account in real-time.
This can lead to increased lead generation, improved conversion rates, and higher ROI.

Outbound lead generation techniques | Quick Take: Respect people’s time. If you’re going to initiate contact, have a plan. Do research. Understand the value you can offer, and deliver that promise quickly.

While inbound strategies (e.g., content marketing) work to attract leads to you, outbound lead generation takes the initiative with proactive outreach. If you master the following techniques, you’ll be in the driver’s seat, accelerating your lead acquisition and expanding your business’s reach.

Cold calling and cold emailing | Your ideal customer may not always come knocking on your door, but that doesn’t mean you can’t reach out and introduce yourself. Cold calling and cold emailing are classic outbound lead generation techniques that, when done right, can yield excellent results.

When cold calling, preparation is key. Before picking up the phone, research your prospect and their company.6sense’s guide to B2B prospectingwill help you learn how to understand their pain points, industry challenges, and how your product or service can provide solutions. Craft a concise and compelling script that highlights the value you can offer.

During the call, be polite, professional, and respectful of the prospect’s time. Clearly state your purpose and how your offering can benefit them. Remember that the goal of the initial call is not necessarily to close a deal but to establish a connection and interest.

Cold emailing | Cold emailing, like cold calling, requires careful planning. Start with a compelling subject line that piques curiosity and encourages the recipient to open the email. Keep the email concise, focusing on the recipient’s needs and the benefits your solution brings.

Personalization is particularly crucial in cold emailing. Address the recipient by name, mention specific pain points or challenges relevant to their industry, and provide a clear call to action (CTA). Whether you want them to schedule a call, download a resource, or request a demo, make the next steps easy and enticing.

LinkedIn outreach | Your LinkedIn outreach strategy should begin by optimizing your profile. It should reflect your expertise, industry experience, and the value you offer. Also, make sure to use a professional profile picture and craft a compelling headline and summary.

Next, identify and connect with decision-makers, potential leads, and individuals in your target industry or niche. Followbest practices for LinkedIn outreach, such as personalizing your connection requests and InMail messages by mentioning a common interest or mutual connection. Also, avoid overly salesy language and instead aim to begin a meaningful conversation.

Direct mail campaigns | In today’s digital age, direct mail may seem old-fashioned, but it can be a highly effective outbound lead generation technique, especially when targeting a specific audience. Direct mail campaigns involve sending prospects physical marketing materials, such as postcards, brochures, or personalized letters.

The success of a direct mail campaign lies in its personalization and relevance. Start by creating a targeted list of recipients who align with your ideal customer profile. This could be based on industry, location, company size, or other relevant criteria.

Make sure to personalize your direct mail pieces to resonate with the recipient. Mention specific pain points or challenges they may be facing and highlight how your solution addresses them. Don’t forget also to include a clear call to action.

Measuring and optimizing outbound efforts | Outbound lead generation efforts require continuous refinement and optimization to maximize their effectiveness. Here are some critical tips to measure and improve your outbound strategies:
Lead generation best practices | Quick Take: Talk with your sales team, use shared success metrics, and experiment.

Regardless of the specific lead generation tactic you decide to use, there are some best practices that can significantly enhance your chances of success. These practices serve as guiding principles for crafting and executing effective lead generation strategies.

A/B testing landing pages and emails | A/B testing, also known as split testing, is a lead generation best practice that involves creating two or more versions of a webpage, email, or other marketing asset to compare their performance. Doing this lets you determine which version resonates best with your audience and yields higher conversion rates.

For example, in A/B testing landing pages, you might create two variations of a page with different headlines, images, or call-to-action buttons. Directing equal traffic to both versions allows you to analyze which generates more leads or conversions.

Continuous data analysis involves monitoring and assessingmetrics and KPIsrelated to your lead generation efforts. This includes tracking website traffic, conversion rates, email open and click-through rates, and more.

By regularly reviewing your data, you can spot underperforming elements and refine your strategies. For example, if you notice a drop in email engagement, you can experiment with different subject lines or content types to re-engage your audience.

Building and maintaining a robust sales funnel | A well-structured sales funnel is essential for guiding leads through the journey from initial awareness to becoming paying customers. It consists of distinct stages, such as awareness, consideration, and decision, each with its own marketing and sales activities.

To optimize your lead generation strategy, map out your sales funnel and make sure it aligns with your buyer’s journey. Understand your leads’ needs and questions at each stage and provide relevant content and touchpoints to nurture them through the funnel. Make sure to also regularly review and update your sales funnel to adapt to changing market conditions and customer behaviors.
Sales and marketing alignment | Ineffective communication and collaboration between sales and marketing teams can hinder lead generation efforts.

On the other hand, when sales and marketing teams are aligned, they share a common understanding of the ideal customer profile, lead qualification criteria, and the lead handoff process. They also collaborate on content creation, messaging, and lead nurturing strategies.

Let’s dig deeper to understand what ICP actually is and how to define one for your organization.

What Is an Ideal customer profile (ICP)? | An ICP is a fictitious organization that’s a perfect fit for your product or service. A customer who matches your ICP characteristics is likely to buy your product or service, remain loyal, and recommend it.
While at times the ideal customer profile might include information about individual buyers, more often it is defined clearly when setting up buyer personas (see below).
An ideal customer profile is set up based on analyzing retrospective data derived from all the previous companies your organization has sold to.

As mentioned before, an ideal customer profile affects not just your sales teams but also other teams in your organization. Therefore, it is important that various departments of your organization to work together to define what your ICP will be.
Difference between Ideal Customer Profile and Buyer Personas | ICP is the fictional profile of an organization you want to sell to.
Buyer personas are semi-fictional representations of the buying team members who will be deciding whether to purchase, and the motivations that drive their decisions.

Buyer personas take into account demographic data, goals of these individuals, pain points, and more. Using buyer personas, marketers can work towards developing the right kind of content for these sets of individuals.
To understand these differences better let us consider a fictitious company which specializes in solar panels installations called Solar Loom.
Why Do You Need Both, an Ideal Customer Profile and Buyer Persona? | Use your ICP use identify the accounts that make sense for your go-to-market efforts.
Once the ideal accounts are identified, then buyer personas can help determine how to sell to the decision makers.
The best way to visualize the need for ICPs and buyer personas is this — ICPs help identify target organizations while buyer personas can help in communicating with the individual.

Outbound Wins | The sales team implemented “power hours” two times each week where every BDR hit the phone for 90 minutes straight, calling down an account list they prepared in advance by researching accounts’ intent and profile scores, along with their recent activity on the web.

title: ABM Templates: Build Your Strategic Foundation Before You Scale | 6sense
meta_description: Hone your account-based marketing strategy with our tailored ABM planning templates. Step-by-step lists for identifying ICP and planning content and handoffs.
p: Account-based marketing has evolved dramatically since its early days, when companies struggled to scale personalized campaigns beyond a handful of target accounts. Limited resources forced teams to make strategic compromises — broader messaging, less personalization, fewer touchpoints – just to cover their account list. | What specific characteristics define your highest-value accounts? | How should messaging adapt across different buying committee roles? | Which content assets create the most impact at each buying stage?

Platforms like 6sense enable teams to execute highly personalized, multi-touch campaigns across hundreds of accounts without scaling compromises. But this capability creates a new challenge:there’sno point automating a poorly designed strategy.
The teams achieving breakthrough ABM results aren’t just scaling faster — they’re scaling better strategies.
That’s where ABM templates become essential. These strategic frameworks help practitioners think through the critical elements of effective account-based marketing before they scale.

Why strategic foundation matters more than ever | The rise of sophisticated ABM platforms has created new possibilities for scaling personalized campaigns, but scaling capabilities without strategic clarity leads to scaled mediocrity.
The most successful ABM programs start with thorough strategic planning that examines every element of their approach before execution begins.
These aren’t technical implementation questions — they’re strategic decisions that require careful examination.

ABM templates provide structured frameworks for working through these strategic considerations systematically. Rather than jumping into execution with loosely-defined approaches, these templates guide teams through comprehensive strategic planning that creates stronger foundations for scaling.
Four essential ABM templates for strategic planning | The following ABM templates help practitioners examine and refine the strategic elements that determine campaign effectiveness.

This ICP templateguides comprehensive examination of your target account characteristics, ensuring you’ve identified the specific attributes that correlate with success rather than relying on broad assumptions. Thorough ICP development prevents the common mistake of scaling campaigns to accounts that look right but don’t convert.
Strategic value:A well-examined ICP ensures every scaled campaign targets accounts with genuine potential, reducing waste and maximizing ROI.

This account qualification templatehelps teams think through the specific criteria that indicate genuine buying potential versus surface-level engagement. Clear qualification frameworks prevent teams from spending too much time and money on accounts that aren’t truly in-market.
Strategic value:Comprehensive qualification criteria focus resources on accounts that are likely to generate revenue rather than spreading efforts across accounts showing false positive signals.

This messaging framework templateprovides consideration of how messaging should adapt across account characteristics, competitive landscapes, and buying committee roles. Thorough messaging planning ensures scaled campaigns maintain relevance and impact rather than defaulting to generic approaches.
Strategic value:Well-planned messaging frameworks enable teams to scale personalized communication without losing the strategic positioning that drives results.

This content mapping templatehelps teams examine which content assets create an impact across different account types and buying stages. Strategic content planning ensures campaigns have the right materials to support each account’s specific journey.
Strategic value:Comprehensive content mapping helps you deliver a buyer experience that is tailored to individual needs, which builds trust and sets the groundwork for sales conversations and deals.

Use templates for deep strategic examination | Don’t rush through ABM template completion. Instead, use them as frameworks for comprehensive strategic discussions with your team. Each section should prompt thorough consideration of assumptions, alternatives, and strategic implications before moving forward.

Customize templates for your strategic context | Adapt ABM templates based on your industry, competitive landscape, and organizational dynamics. Generic templates provide structure, but strategic value comes from customizing frameworks to address your specific strategic challenges and opportunities.

Involve cross-functional teams in template development | ABM strategy benefits from diverse perspectives. Include sales, marketing, and customer success teams in template completion to ensure your strategic foundation reflects a comprehensive understanding of account dynamics and buyer behavior.

Regular strategic review and refinement | Market conditions and buyer behavior evolve continuously. Schedule regular reviews of your ABM templates to ensure your strategic foundation remains relevant and effective as you scale campaigns.

From strategic foundation to scalable execution | ABM templates create the strategic clarity that makes scaling possible without compromising effectiveness. Teams that invest time in comprehensive strategic planning build foundations that support sophisticated execution across large account lists.

The transformation is significant: instead of choosing between personalized campaigns for few accounts or generic campaigns for many accounts, teams can now scale highly personalized strategies without strategic compromises. But this advantage only materializes when scaling is built on solid strategic foundations.

Modern ABM success requires both strategic rigor and execution capability.Use these ABM templates to build comprehensive strategic foundations, then leverage platforms like 6sense to execute those well-designed strategies at scale.

title: The Complete Guide to ABM Strategy: Frameworks for Success
meta_description: What is ABM strategy? This complete and in-depth guide will walk you through the ins-and-outs of ABM strategy from beginning to end.
p: Okay, ugly truth time: There is a huge gulf between ABM adoption and actual ABM success in B2B marketing. The reason: A lot of ABM strategy is hampered by inadequate buy-in and half-measures. | 40% reductions in campaign execution time, | 37% increases in engagement rates, and | 14% improvementsin pipeline conversion.

While8 out of 10 B2B organizations report having an ABM program,only 20% reporttheir programs are fully embedded in business operations. And it creates a big opportunity gap. Companies willing to move beyond basic account targeting — toward sophisticated, AI-powered ABM strategies — enjoy a massive competitive advantage.
The numbers tell a compelling story.91% ofcompanies implementing comprehensive ABM strategies see average deal size increase, and97% reporthigher ROI than traditional marketing.
The convergence of artificial intelligence and intent data has fundamentally transformed what’s possible with ABM strategy.Companies using AI-powered ABMsee

Intent data, now used by91% of B2B marketers, enables unprecedented precision in account targeting and timing, with companies likeSiemensachieving remarkable transformations from 1% to 90% sales acceptance of marketing-qualified leads.
This guide reveals how modern ABM strategies leverage these technological advances to create sustainable competitive advantages.

ABM strategy goes far beyond tactical execution like personalized emails, targeted ads, and account-specific landing pages.True ABM strategy encompasses a fundamental look at your entire go-to-market approach.

The distinction matters. Tactics are important, but strategic ABM addresses deeper questions about market positioning, resource allocation, technology integration, and long-term competitive advantage. It’s the difference between running targeted campaigns and transforming how your organization approaches high-value customer acquisition.

Today’s most successful ABM programs integrate artificial intelligence, predictive analytics, and real-time intent data to create “always-on” account engagement. Rather than launching discrete campaigns, these organizations maintain continuous, personalized interactions with target accounts based on buying signals, competitive dynamics, and engagement depth.

The most effective strategies incorporateintent signalsandpredictive analyticsto identify accounts that are ready to buy and have the highest revenue potential. This evolution matters because43% of organizations strugglewith target selection. Sophisticated account intelligence is a crucial competitive advantage.

If you’re not strategically engaging the entire buying team, you’re missing an opportunity to win more opportunities and close more deals. Enterprise purchasing decisions now involve anaverage of 14stakeholders, each with different priorities, information consumption preferences, and influence levels. Across companies of all sizes, the average buying group consists of 11 people.

Technology and automation framework | The most successful ABM strategies integrate multiple technology platforms — CRM,  marketing automation, intent data, and AI-powered orchestration tools — to capture customer and share data that enables smooth customer journeys and a smart use of team resources. This integration becomes crucial as marketing teams manage increasingly complex multi-channel campaigns across dozens or hundreds of target accounts.

Performance measurement and optimization | Strategic ABM measures account-level engagement progression, pipeline velocity improvements, and long-term customer value creation. These metrics inform strategic decisions about resource allocation, technology investment, and market focus.

The financial impact of strategic ABM becomes clear when examining performance differences between organizations with mature programs versus those still operating at campaign level. Companies with mature strategies report234% faster pipeline progressionfor ad-influenced accounts and65%of companies report improvements in customer lifetime value.

Competitive advantage through AI and intent data | The integration of artificial intelligence into ABM strategies enables fundamentally different strategic approaches. AI-powered platforms can analyze billions of signals to identify research being done by specific accounts, predict account behavior, understand buying stages, and personalize interactions at scale previously impossible with manual processes.

Intent dataprovides the foundation for proactive ABM strategies. Instead of waiting for accounts to express interest through form fills or direct inquiries, organizations can identify accounts showing early-stage buying signals and engage before competitors recognize the opportunity.This first-mover advantage becomes crucial in competitive markets where timing often determines win/loss outcomes.

The technology evolution also addresses scalability challenges that previously limited ABM to small account sets. Modern platforms enable personalized engagement across hundreds or thousands of accounts while maintaining the relevance and timing that drive ABM effectiveness. This scalability allows organizations to reach more of their addressable market while preserving the high-touch engagement that accounts demand.

Example:BioCatchused AI-powered account targeting to achieve a 63% increase in accounts reaching active engagement stage. The results came not from strategic changes in account identification, engagement timing, and multi-channel orchestration made possibly by AI that gathered and analyzed intent data, then fed those insights into campaign execution.

The modern ABM strategy framework | Building effective ABM strategy requires moving beyond ad hoc campaign approaches toward systematic frameworks that address account selection, technology integration, and performance optimization. The most successful organizations follow structured approaches that balance strategic planning with execution flexibility, allowing them to maintain consistency while adapting to market changes and account-specific opportunities.

The framework outlined below reflects best practices from organizations achieving the highest ABM performance levels.Rather than prescriptive step-by-step processes, it provides strategic guidance that can be adapted to different industries, company sizes, and technology environments while maintaining the core elements that drive ABM success.

Account identification and prioritizationforms the cornerstone of strategic ABM success. Unlike traditional approaches that rely primarily on basic firmographic criteria — company size, industry, geography — modern account selection integrates predictive analytics, intent signals, and competitive intelligence to identify accounts with the highest revenue potential and optimal engagement timing.

Advanced account selection incorporates multiple data sources and analytical approaches. Predictive analytics identify accounts showing characteristics similar to your best customers, while intent data reveals accounts actively researching solutions in your category. Competitive intelligence helps prioritize accounts where you have positioning advantages or existing relationship foundations.

Successful technology strategies prioritize integration over individual platform capabilities. The goal involves creating seamless data flow between account identification, engagement orchestration, and performance measurement systems. Organizations achieving the best results use unified platforms that eliminate manual data transfer and enable real-time optimization based on account engagement signals.

Modern ABM platforms integrate artificial intelligence and machine learning to automate routine decisions while providing human teams with actionable insights. This automation becomes crucial as campaigns scale beyond manual management capabilities. Intelligent workflows can automatically adjust messaging, timing, and channel selection based on account behavior while maintaining the personalization that drives ABM effectiveness.
Multi-channel orchestration | Effective orchestration requires sophisticated coordination across email, social media, content marketing, advertising, and sales outreach activities.

Intelligent workflow automationaddresses this complexity by enabling dynamic campaign adjustments based on real-time account signals. Rather than using static audience lists that are never updated frequently enough, these systems shift accounts and known contacts into specific campaign sequences based on their behavior — which keeps messaging on-point and delivers a cohesive buyer journey across touchpoints.
Sales and marketing alignment | Alignment extends beyond shared metrics to include integrated processes, unified technology platforms, and collaborative account planning.

AfterJAGGAERintegrated 6sense with their existing technology stack and establishing unified workflows between sales and marketing teams, they achieved $77,459 in cost savings during the first two months while engaging 147 unique accounts and moving 129 accounts to sales development representative sequences.

AI enables hyper-personalization capabilities that were previously impossible at enterprise scale, but strategiccontent planning must address diverse stakeholder needs, varying industry requirements, and different stages of the buying journey.

Account-specific content goes beyond inserting company names into email templates. Strategic personalization addresses specific business challenges, regulatory requirements, competitive positioning, and integration considerations relevant to each target account. This depth of customization requires significant content investment but generates proportionally higher engagement and conversion rates.
Campaign execution | Modern platforms can manage complex, multi-touch sequences across multiple channels while adapting to real-time conditions .

FireMonachieved 34% click-through rates, 50% increases in buyer engagement behavior, and 100% daily 6sense login rates among sellers by implementing comprehensive multi-channel campaigns powered by intelligent workflows. These results came from strategic technology integration rather than tactical campaign improvements.

Real-time optimization capabilities distinguish strategic ABM from campaign-based approaches. Rather than analyzing performance after campaign completion, advanced systems provide continuous feedback that enables immediate adjustments to messaging, timing, and channel selection. This responsiveness becomes crucial for maintaining engagement throughout extended enterprise sales cycles.

Performance monitoring | While traditional marketing measures impressions, clicks, and conversion rates, strategic ABM focuses on account-level engagement progression, pipeline velocity improvements, and long-term customer value creation.

The most successful programs track account penetration (engagement across multiple stakeholders), relationship depth (frequency and quality of interactions), and competitive positioning (comparative engagement versus competitors). These metrics inform strategic decisions about resource allocation, technology investment, and market focus rather than simple campaign optimization.

Technology integration: The AI advantage | Many organizations select point solutions for specific functions without considering workflow integration, data synchronization, or scalability requirements that determine long-term success.

The legacy technology challenge | Modern ABM technology stacks typically include 8-12 core tools requiring careful integration planning. The proliferation of point solutions creates complexity without delivering proportional value.AI-powered ABM capabilities

Intent data and predictive analytics | Intent data continues evolving. Early implementations focused on keyword-based signals, but modern platforms analyze behavioral patterns, content consumption sequences, and competitive research activities to provide nuanced insights into account readiness and priority topics. This evolution enables more precise engagement strategies that address specific account interests rather than generic industry messaging.

Predictive analytics complement intent data by identifying accounts showing characteristics similar to successful customers before they demonstrate obvious buying signals. These capabilities enable proactive engagement that positions organizations as thought leaders rather than reactive vendors responding to explicit requests for information.

The technology integration extends beyond marketing activities to include sales enablement, customer success, and account management functions. This comprehensive approach ensures consistent account experiences throughout the entire customer lifecycle rather than limiting ABM to lead generation activities.

Ongoing learning to improve performance | Organizations with mature AI implementations achieve 3x increases in sales-qualified leads, while machine learning models continuously improve targeting precision based on performance data and market feedback.

Continuous learning capabilities distinguish AI-powered ABM from static campaign approaches. These systems analyze engagement patterns, conversion outcomes, and competitive dynamics to refine account selection, messaging optimization, and timing recommendations. The result involves constantly improving performance without requiring manual analysis and adjustment.

CRM synchronization and data flow | Successful integration ensures account engagement data flows seamlessly between marketing automation, sales engagement, and customer relationship management systems without requiring duplicate data entry or manual reporting. Using a CDP to connect data across the tech stack creates a single source of truth that can be regularly updated and keep tools synced.

Advanced integration approaches create unified account records that combine intent signals, engagement history, sales activities, and relationship mapping. This comprehensive view enables sophisticated account planning that addresses multiple stakeholders, competitive dynamics, and relationship development opportunities.

Marketing automation enhancement | Marketing automation becomes more powerful when integrated with ABM platforms. This combination enables sophisticated nurture strategies that respond to account-specific signals rather than generic demographic triggers.

Measuring ABM strategy success | Strategic ABM measurement requires fundamentally different approaches than traditional marketing metrics. While campaign-based marketing might track impressions, clicks, and lead conversion rates, strategic ABM focuses on account-level engagement progression, relationship development, and long-term business impact metrics that reflect the multi-stakeholder, extended-cycle nature of enterprise B2B sales.

The measurement evolution reflects broader changes in B2B buying behavior and sales cycle complexity. Traditional funnel metrics assume linear progression from awareness to consideration to purchase, but enterprise ABM involves multiple stakeholders, non-linear evaluation processes, and relationship-building activities that standard metrics cannot capture effectively.

Primary metricsfor strategic ABM focus on business outcomes rather than marketing activities. Account engagement scores combine multiple interaction types, stakeholder levels, and engagement frequency to provide comprehensive views of account relationship strength and progression.

Pipeline influence and revenue attribution require sophisticated tracking that connects marketing activities to sales outcomes across extended time periods. This attribution becomes complex because strategic ABM involves multiple touchpoints, diverse content types, and relationship-building activities that may not directly correlate with immediate sales activities.

Common challenges and solutions | Strategic ABM implementation involves complex organizational, technological, and process challenges. Understanding these common obstacles and proven solutions helps organizations avoid predictable pitfalls while building sustainable ABM capabilities.

Data reliability challenges | Poor account identification undermines personalization efforts, misdirects resource allocation, and creates measurement problems that make optimization impossible. These data problems often stem from fragmented systems, incomplete integration, and lack of data governance processes.

The data quality issues extend beyond simple accuracy to include timeliness, completeness, and relevance for strategic decision-making. Account information that’s six months old may miss organizational changes, technology adoptions, or competitive developments that significantly impact engagement strategies and messaging relevance.

Successful organizations address data challenges throughsystematic data auditing, multiple source validation, and continuous updating processes. Rather than relying on single data sources, they integrate multiple intelligence platforms and establish regular data quality reviews that maintain accuracy over time.

Measurement complexity | Traditional marketing measurement approaches don’t translate effectively to account-based strategies that involve multiple stakeholders, extended time periods, and relationship-building activities that may not correlate directly with immediate sales outcomes.

The attribution challenges become particularly complex because strategic ABM influences multiple stakeholders across extended buying cycles. Connecting specific marketing activities to ultimate sales outcomes requires sophisticated tracking systems and analytical approaches that many organizations lack experience implementing.

Advanced measurement solutions require technology integration, process standardization, and analytical capabilities that extend beyond traditional marketing requirements. Organizations achieving measurement success invest in unified platforms, cross-functional analytics teams, and executive education about ABM measurement complexities.

Technology and integration challenges | Platform proliferation creates operational complexity without delivering proportional value improvements. Many organizations accumulate multiple point solutions for specific functions without considering integration requirements, workflow efficiency, or long-term scalability needs.

Data synchronization issues between marketing automation, CRM, and ABM platforms create accuracy problems that undermine strategic decision-making. When different systems contain conflicting account information or engagement data, teams make decisions based on incomplete or inaccurate information that reduces ABM effectiveness.

Training and adoption requirements for complex technology stacks often exceed organizational capabilities, leading to low utilization rates and missed functionality. Without comprehensive training programs and ongoing support, sophisticated platforms become expensive tools that teams avoid rather than strategic assets that drive performance improvements.

Phased implementation approaches | Rather than attempting comprehensive implementation immediately, successful organizations begin with pilot programs that demonstrate value and build internal expertise before scaling to larger account sets.

The crawl-walk-run methodology provides proven framework for sustainable ABM development. Organizations begin with basic account identification and targeted content, progress through personalized engagement and measurement implementation, and ultimately achieve advanced automation and optimization capabilities.

Change management best practices | Strategic ABM requires changes in team structures, process workflows, and success metrics that can create internal resistance without proper change management approaches.

Executive sponsorship becomes crucial for overcoming organizational inertia and resource allocation challenges. ABM initiatives often require cross-functional cooperation and process changes that need executive support to implement successfully.

Future of ABM strategy | The ABM landscape will experience fundamental transformation through 2027, driven by advancing AI capabilities, evolving buyer expectations, and economic pressures that demand greater efficiency and measurable results. Organizations building ABM strategies today must anticipate these changes to ensure their investments remain competitive and their capabilities scale with market evolution.
Multi-agent AI systems | These systems will manage complex, multi-channel engagement strategies while adapting to real-time account behavior and competitive dynamics without manual intervention.

The multi-agent approach addresses scalability limitations that currently constrain ABM to relatively small account sets. By automating routine decision-making and optimization activities, these systems will enable personalized engagement across thousands of accounts while maintaining the relevance and timing that drive ABM effectiveness.

Real-time multimodal AI will integrate data from diverse sources — sensors, social signals, behavioral patterns, and competitive intelligence — to create comprehensive account intelligence that exceeds human analytical capabilities. This integration will enable sophisticated engagement strategies based on subtle signals and pattern recognition that manual processes cannot identify.
Intent-based orchestration | These systems will recognize engagement patterns, competitive activities, and buying stage progression to optimize messaging, timing, and channel selection continuously.

The orchestration sophistication will extend beyond marketing activities to include sales enablement, customer success, and account management coordination. This comprehensive approach will ensure consistent account experiences throughout the entire customer lifecycle rather than limiting automation to lead generation activities.

Predictive pipeline acceleration will forecast deal closure probability based on engagement patterns, competitive positioning, and historical performance data. These forecasts will inform strategic decisions about resource allocation, territory planning, and investment priorities with accuracy levels that support confident business planning.

Full-funnel lifecycle management | This ABM focus reflects the reality that customer lifetime value optimization requires coordinated strategies throughout the entire relationship rather than ending at initial purchase.

The lifecycle approach integrates marketing automation, sales enablement, and customer success activities into unified strategies that maximize account value over time. This integration requires organizational changes, integrated technology platforms, and measurement approaches that track long-term relationship development rather than transaction-focused metrics.

Account expansion strategies will become increasingly sophisticated, using AI to identify upsell and cross-sell opportunities based on usage patterns, organizational changes, and competitive developments. These capabilities will enable proactive account management that increases customer lifetime value while strengthening competitive positioning.
Technology investment planning | Organizations should focus on platforms that provide strong integration APIs, scalable architecture, and regular capability updates rather than static feature lists.

The platform selection criteria will shift toward AI-native solutions that incorporate machine learning throughout their functionality rather than traditional platforms with AI features added as supplements. This architectural difference will determine long-term competitive capabilities as AI integration becomes more sophisticated.
Skill development requirements | Marketing teams will need capabilities in data analysis, strategy development, and technology orchestration rather than manual campaign management.

The organizational structure evolution will favor cross-functional teams that combine marketing, sales, and customer success expertise with technology and analytical capabilities. These integrated teams will manage account relationships more effectively than traditional functional silos.

Investment in continuous learning and adaptation capabilities will become crucial as AI reshapes business and behavior. Organizations that develop strong learning cultures and change management capabilities will adapt more successfully.

Building your ABM strategy | Organizations beginning ABM strategic development should prioritize foundation building over rapid scaling. The crawl-walk-run methodology provides proven framework for sustainable capability development that builds internal expertise while demonstrating measurable value to secure ongoing investment and organizational support.
This phase establishes measurement baselines, identifies process gaps, and builds team capabilities before scaling to larger initiatives.
This phase requires technology integration, organizational process development, and measurement system implementation that support sustainable scaling.

Organizations maintaining commitment through this development period achieve sustainable competitive advantages that compound over time, while those expecting immediate returns often abandon strategic approaches before realizing their potential value.

Strategic ABM represents more than marketing technique evolution — it embodies fundamental changes in how B2B organizations approach high-value customer acquisition, relationship development, and competitive positioning. Companies mastering these strategic elements will build sustainable advantages in increasingly complex and competitive markets, while those treating ABM as tactical campaign enhancement will miss the transformative potential that defines modern B2B marketing success.

The evidence overwhelmingly demonstrates that strategic ABM delivers transformative business results when implemented with appropriate technology, organizational alignment, and measurement sophistication.

Conclusion | The transformation from traditional B2B marketing to strategic ABM represents a fundamental shift in how organizations build relationships with their most valuable prospects and customers.
The evidence is compelling: companies implementing comprehensive ABM strategies see up to 208% revenueincreasesand 97% report higher ROI than traditional approaches.
But these resultsdon’tcome from simply adopting new tools or running targeted campaigns.
Success in strategic ABM requires three critical foundations working in harmony.

Technology integrationmust go beyond point solutions to create unified platforms that enable intelligent automation while keeping the personalization that drives engagement. The 94% of professionals who prefer integrated solutions over disparate tools understand this reality from hard experience.
Organizational alignmentbetween sales and marketing teams determines whether sophisticated technology investments translate into business impact or remain expensive underutilized resources.

Measurement sophisticationthat tracks account-level progression and relationship depth rather than campaign metrics provides the insights needed for continuous optimization and strategic decision-making.

The organizations thriving in this new landscape share a common characteristic: they view ABM as a strategic business capability rather than a marketing tactic. They invest in change management, executive sponsorship, and cross-functional processes that enable sustained competitive advantage.
They understand that the crawl-walk-run implementation approach builds internal expertise and demonstrates value before scaling to enterprise-wide initiatives.

Looking ahead, the convergence of AI, intent data, and predictive analytics will only accelerate the advantages available to organizations with mature ABM strategies. Multi-agent AI systems and real-time optimization capabilities will enable personalized engagement at unprecedented scale.

The organizations that combine advanced capabilities with strategic thinking, organizational alignment, and measurement sophistication will build sustainable competitive moats in increasingly complex B2B markets.
The choice facing B2B organizations today isn’t whether to adopt ABM — it’s whether to approach it strategically or tactically.

Those choosing the strategic path and committing to the foundational elements outlined in this guide will find themselves well-positioned to capitalize on the transformative potential that defines the future of B2B marketing success.

The measurement evolution from activity-based to outcome-based metrics requires analytical capabilities and technology integration that extend beyond traditional marketing requirements. However, this investment enables optimization and resource allocation decisions thatdeterminelong-term ABM effectiveness and business impact.

p: About the Episode: | In this episode, Kerry draws a powerful parallel between an infamous World War II holdout and the outdated war many B2B marketers are still fighting today: the battle to improve MQL production and conversion. | The Hiroo Onoda Analogy: What a decades-late WWII surrender can teach us about marketing inertia and cognitive dissonance. | The MQL Obsession: Why many B2B marketers are still committed to a lead gen strategy that no longer delivers value. | Evidence Against MQL Effectiveness: Real data from buyer experience studies showing form fills and early engagement are rare. | Buyer-Controlled Journeys: How buyers dictate the terms and timing of engagement, regardless of seller outreach. | Shortlist Dynamics: Understanding how buyers decide which vendors make the shortlist well before sales ever gets involved. | Buying Group Enablement: The importance of reaching not just primary buyers, but influential roles like finance and procurement. | AI & Automation for Relevance: How AI-driven orchestration can scale personalized engagement based on in-market signals. | Letting Go of the Form-Fill Fallacy: Why valuable content should be accessible without gating and how to reframe marketing success.

Just as Japanese officer Hiroo Onoda remained in the jungle decades after WWII had ended, many marketers remain entrenched in the MQL mindset — committed to a cause that no longer serves the modern buyer, sales teams, or even marketing itself.

Kerry uses historical context, buyer behavior data, and real-world survey findings to dismantle the myth that we can dictate buyer timing or manufacture meaningful engagement through gated content. Instead, he advocates a buyer-centric, signal-based strategy that aligns with how B2B buying actually happens.

meta_description: AI-Powered B2B relies on comprehensive data that is accurate and up-to-date data. Dive into the Signalverse™️, the massive collection of data signals that feed 6sense AI and power B2B growth.
p: Executive Summary | Making a big change in your marketing strategy can be overwhelming. You’ve relied on Marketing Qualified Leads (MQLs) for years, and shifting away might seem like a huge leap. But here’s the truth: sticking with MQLs doesn’t just keep you in your comfort zone — it holds you back from real growth. | Top market leaders, | Data from 6sense’s Global Buyer Experience Report, and | Findings from our independent poll and survey of marketing and demand generation leaders
This report shows you how to get better results with the resources you already have. We’ve gathered insights from…
… to help you understand why moving beyond MQLs isn’t just necessary — it’s an opportunity to do more with less stress.
By shifting your focus away from MQLs towards Marketing Qualified Accounts (MQAs), you can achieve real impact without burning out. AI Can help you:
This report will guide you through the process, providing actionable insights and strategies to help you navigate the Signalverse™ and drive meaningful results for your business.
6sense’s AI-powered platform leads this shift, enabling marketers to navigate the Signalverse effectively.

The Changing Landscape of B2B Marketing | If you’ve relied on MQLs, you’ve likely felt the frustration of watching leads that look great on paper fail to translate into actual sales. It’s not your fault. B2B sales have changed dramatically, and MQLs no longer cut it.

Our recent poll reveals a stark reality:only 2.7% of Marketing and Demand Gen leaders feel MQLs are the most important metric for their business. If you feel stuck, you’re not alone-and this report will show you a less stressful, more effective way forward.

The B2B Marketing landscape has undergone a seismic shift. Buyers now conduct extensive research independently, involve multiple stakeholders in their organization, and often prefer digital interactions over traditional sales engagements.These changes underscore the need for a fundamental rethink of our approach to marketing and sales. It’s time to move beyond the limitations of MQLs and embrace the rich tapestry of signals that buyers send — what we call the Signalverse™.
“MQLs don’t tell us the full story, we need to rethink how we measure success if we want to keep up.”

Understanding the Signalverse | Today’s B2B buyers leave digital signals at every turn, forming a “Signalverse” — a rich blend of data points that, when harnessed, gives us a deeper look at buyer behavior.

The 6sense Signalverse™ is a powerful data engine that processes over one trillion signals every day—ranging from third-party intent and website activity to MAP and CRM engagement. It analyses the last 12 weeks of behaviour to calculate precise scores and insights for each individual day, giving teams a continuously updated view of buyer activity.

This includes over 20 billion daily intent signals, such as keyword research and external content consumption, combined with engagement data from marketing automation and CRM systems. All of this is processed by AI to fuel 6sense’s capabilities — web deanonymization, buying stage prediction, personalised engagement, and intelligent recommendations — so B2B marketers and sellers can identify and connect with the right buyers at exactly the right time.
But what does this mean for you? | Imagine gaining visibility into the future of your pipeline. Here’s what the Signalverse can help you achieve:

Today’s B2B buyers make most of their critical purchasing decisions independently, long before they ever fill out a form or speak to sales. The Signalverse™ lets you detect and influence these buying groups during their critical research and selection phase, then engage them meaningfully when they’re ready for direct contact. By prioritizing accounts based on intent and engagement signals, your teams can focus on the opportunities most likely to convert. This shift from reactive to proactive engagement means building preference with potential buyers when it matters most-during their independent evaluation process.

Throughout this guide, we’ll explore how the Signalverse™ helps you align with modern buying behavior by identifying and engaging accounts during their research phase, ensuring you’re the preferred vendor when they’re ready to make contact. Learn how to move beyond traditional MQLs to a predictive, account-based strategy that matches how B2B purchases really happen.

Your blueprint for success | 6sense has distilled the complexities of modern B2B marketing into a straightforward, five-step formula. This approach is designed to help you navigate the Signalverse™ and ensure you’re targeting the right accounts at the right time with the right message.

Identify the accounts that are most likely to benefit from your solution. Use 6sense’s AI-driven insights to narrow down yourIdeal Customer Profile (ICP)to the accounts that are actively looking for a solution and focus your efforts where they’ll have the most impact.

Ensure that your marketing and sales teams areworking from the same playbook. Share data, insights, and goals to create a seamless experience for the buyer. When both teams are aligned, you’re more likely to close deals and retain customers.

Focus on metrics that matter. Instead of relying on vanity metrics like MQLs, track pipeline impact, revenue growth, and account engagement. Use these metrics to continuously refine your strategy to drive better results

The 70/30 split: the new paradigm | 6sense research reveals a crucial insight: B2B buyers spend approximately 70% of their journey researching independently before engaging with vendors. This period is where preferences and shortlists emerge – and where the Signalverse™ is essential.
“Buyers don’t talk to sellers until 70 percent of the way through the journey on average, and when they do, they have already picked a favorite and rarely change from that favorite.”
Global Buyer Experience Insights | The 2024 Buyer Experience Report reveals key trends across NA, EMEA and APAC:
Buying group dynamics | Globally, B2B purchases typically involve nine to 12 stakeholders, collaborating to and select solutions.

Extended decision process | The average B2B buying journey spans 11.5 moths, with regional variations – 10.2 months in EMEA, 11.2 months in North America, and 13.2 months in APAC. This underscores the importance of sustained engagement.
Multiple vendor evaluations | B2B buying team consider four to five vendors before deciding, reinforcing the need to differentiate early in the process.
Late-stage engagement | Buyers don’t reach out to vendors until they are 69% through their decision process, making early-stage marketing and digital visibility essential.
Buyer-driven contact | Globally, 81% of buyers initiate the first contact with vendors, emphasizing the need for strong inbound strategies to attract and engage prospects.

Pre-set requirements | Before engaging with vendors, 85% of buyers have already established their purchase requirements, highlighting the importance of early stage thought leadership and content to influence purchases.

Early favorites win | At the time of first contact, over 80% of buyers already have a preferred vendor in mind. Once engagement begins, the vendor at the top of the shortlist wins the business 84% of the time, reinforcing the importance of brand presence and credibility during independent research.
6sense data shows that the average Global B2Bbuying groupinvolves between nine to 12 people, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive account-based approach rather than focusing on individual leads.
Influencing a single lead isn’t good enough. You need toinfluence the entire buying team.
They want value, not just a good deal | Buyers care about what your product can actually do for them, not just its cost. They’re also more comfortable doing everything digitally.

Alex Venusfrom Personio notes, “We now focus on measuring influence and engagement at both the account and individual contact levels. We aggregate data to see the bigger picture at the account level.”
6sense’s platform helps you understand andrespond to these evolving buyer preferencesensuring your message resonates with what truly matters to your prospects.

Low conversion rates | The biggest challenge with MQLs isn’t just inefficiency—it’s the ripple effect of low conversion rates. Our research shows that, on average, only 2.7% of MQLs convert into closed-won deals. That means 97% of the effort spent generating and nurturing MQLs results in little to no revenue impact.

Many leaders we interviewed echoed this frustration. When MQLs don’t lead to real opportunities, they stop being a reliable metric for success. Instead, businesses need a model that reflects true buying intent across the entire account, not just an individual lead.

The need for a holistic approach | By focusing solely on MQLs, you miss out on the rich tapestry of signals that buyers send throughout their journey. You also fail to account for the complexity of modern B2B buying, where multiple stakeholders influence the decision-making process.

6sense research shows that B2B buyers have hundreds of interactions before making a purchase decision. These interactions span various channels and involve multiple stakeholders, further highlighting the limitations of the MQL approach.

Our survey revealed that | 78% of demand generation leaders find it tough to move away from MQLs. You’re not alone in feeling this way, but those who’ve made the switch already see big results—and you can, too.

Shifting to account-based marketing (ABM) | Moving away from MQLs might feel like a leap into the unknown, but shifting to Marketing Qualified Accounts (MQAs) isn’t just smarter – it’s more effective.
Our research shows that 71% of leaders who’ve started focusing on accounts instead of leads have seen better engagement and conversion rates. This isn’t just a new approach – it’s a better one.
“Focusing on MQAs lets us see the whole picture, we’re not just chasing leads – we’re engaging with the entire buying group when they’re ready to buy.”

At the core of our platform lies the 6sense Signalverse™ – a proprietary ecosystem that captures and processes signals from a vast array of sources, including account identification, web activity, intent data, technographics, company and contact data, news, and psychographics. This data is uniquely curated and enriched through our patented AI, transforming the Signalverse™ into a powerful engine for insights.

Unlike traditional platforms, 6sense’s AI doesn’t just collect data – it interprets and applies it. Our technology predicts which accounts are most likely to buy, when they’re ready to make a decision, and which messages will resonate most. This precision allows you to focus your efforts where they’ll have the greatest impact, driving ROI like never before. 6sense data shows that companies leveraging our AI-powered ABM platform see significant improvements in deal velocity and close rates compared to traditional methods.

A 6x increase in opportunity volume, a 10x rise in high-value opportunities over $3 million, and a 34% conversion rate from content syndication-proof of the power of data-driven, account- based marketing.

Powered by the Signalverse™, AI-driven Email Agents automate engagement across every stage of the buying journey, ensuring highly personalized outreach that aligns with each account’s behavior and intent.

Train AI to match your brand’s voice | Avoid robotic-sounding emails by using past high-performing messages as training data.
Use real buyer signals | The more intent data, website engagement, and past interactions you integrate, the smarter and more relevant your Email Agents become.
