title: Legacy Practices, Legacy Metrics | 6sense
meta_description: This companion to the 2025 Marketing Measurement Benchmark examines how B2B teams evaluate non-ABM demand gen, track engagement and intent signals, and report metrics across leadership and compensation structures.
p: This companion report presents additional findings from our2025 Marketing Measurement Benchmark. Because 8 out of 10 B2B organizations reported having an ABM program, the main report focused primarily on how companies measure the success of their account-based efforts.

While this report concludes with additional ABM-related findings that complement the core themes of the main report, itsprimary focus is on how marketing teams evaluate non-ABM demand generation, track engagement and intent signals, and report those metrics across leadership levels and compensation structures.

These findings are based on a sample of 734 B2B marketers, including 634 real responses collected in early 2025 and 100 statistically simulated responses from VC-backed companies to ensure balanced representation across ownership types. For more information on the sample, please see the appendix.

Measurement Practices in Traditional Demand Gen | Non-ABM demand generation refers to traditional marketing efforts aimed at generating leads and driving interest across a broad audience, rather than focusing on a specific list of target accounts. Unlike account-based marketing (ABM), which prioritizes tailored engagement with a defined set of high-value accounts, non-ABM demand gen typically casts a wider net to attract any potential buyers who may be in-market.

These programs often rely on tactics such as content syndication, paid search, broad email campaigns, social advertising, and SEO—measured using metrics like MQLs (Marketing Qualified Leads), lead volume, conversion rates, and form fills. The goal is to build pipeline at scale, even if many of the leads aren’t from high-priority accounts.

MQLs—both produced and converted—are tracked atreliablyhigher rates than all other metrics. Non-MQL leads produced and converted are tracked far less frequently, and their rates differ reliably from every other measure except each other.

Account Engagement and Intent Metrics | Account engagement and intent signals offer critical visibility into buyer behavior across both owned and external channels. Engagement reflects actions taken by individuals within a target account—such as visiting key web pages, attending webinars, or interacting with emails—while intent signals capture broader interest based on off-site research and content consumption. Together, these indicators help marketing teams identify which accounts are actively exploring solutions and where they may be in the buying journey.

Question:Does the organization measure buying group-level engagement (i.e., how many members of a single buying group engage with marketing content/ tactics?)

Question:At what level in the organization do these metrics get reported? | Apart from MQLs (both produced and converted), there is little consistency when it comes to reporting on legacy demand generation efforts.

Legacy Demand Gen Metrics in Compensation Plans | We asked respondents whether any of the metrics they use to evaluate legacy demand generation efforts are tied to variable compensation, such as bonuses or commissions. Responses ranged from none of the metrics to as many as six of the seven we asked about being tied to pay. But those at the high end were rare.

Shown in the figure below, most respondents reported having zeroor just one legacy metric linked to pay. There was no clear consensus on which metric was most linked to pay, though the top mentions were split between MQLs produced and MQLs converted.

ABM Measurement: What Else We Found | In our main 2025 Marketing Measurement Benchmark Report, we outlined the metrics ABM teams use to attribute success and included a brief look at what gets reported to executive leadership. Below, you’ll find an expanded view of that material.
Most ABM Programs Rely on a Mix of Modern and Legacy KPIs | As we have seen each year we have conducted this study, we found that marketers use a mix of modern and legacy metrics.

In our main report, we noted a small but meaningful subset of respondents who showed signs ofsocially desirable responding—a well-documented survey bias where individuals answer in ways they believe will be viewed more favorably. Even when we filter out these responses, the pattern remains: most ABM programs rely on a blend of modern and legacy metrics. This suggests the issue isn’t just one of perception or self-presentation—it’s structural.
Board | Forty-eight percent of organizations practicing ABM report performance metrics related to their ABM efforts to the board.

Senior Company Leadership | Sixty-three percent of organizations practicing ABM report performance metrics related to their ABM efforts to senior company leadership. While these leaders may be more read-in than the Board, the metrics they’re shown still reflect a blend of modern and legacy KPIs.
Senior Marketing Leadership | Sixty-two percent of organizations practicing ABM report performance metrics related to their ABM efforts to senior marketing leadership.

ABM Reporting Distribution Across Leadership Levels | This chart shows how organizations distribute ABM performance reporting across key leadership audiences. While 98% of organizations report to at least one group, there’s little consistency in who gets the update. Just 27% report to all three leadership levels — board, senior company leadership, and senior marketing leadership.

title: Strategy is a Practice Not a Plan | 6sense
meta_description: In this episode, Seth Godin, author of This Is Strategy, joins Saima Rashid and Adam Kaiser for part 1 of a two-part conversation.
p: In this episode,Seth Godin, author ofThis Is Strategy, joins Saima Rashid and Adam Kaiser for part 1 of a two-part conversation. Seth discusses his latest book, This is Strategy, and how it challenges traditional views of what strategy really is. He explains why strategy isn’t about planning or quick wins, but about understanding where you’re headed and who you want to become.

He breaks down how companies like Starbucks and Microsoft have successfully navigated the market by sticking to clear, long-term strategies. Seth also touches on the importance of working within systems and how to shift from focusing on short-term results to embracing long-term thinking.
